importantArticles.headline: The recent market sell-off has opened the door for some good buying opportunities in growth stocks.  Down just over 20% from its highs, Amazon (NASDAQ: AMZN) is trading at one of its lowest valuations in its history with a trailing price-to-earnings ratio (P/E) of around 34.  The company's cloud computing business, Amazon Web Services (AWS), has been its biggest growth driver, as the company helps customers create and deploy their own artificial intelligence (AI) models and apps on its platform through the help of its Bedrock and SageMaker services.
importantArticles.title: 4 Growth Stocks Down 20% or More to Buy Right Now

importantArticles.headline: Growth stocks are not for the faint of heart.  In bear markets -- like the one investors are experiencing in April 2025 for the Nasdaq Composite Index -- growth stocks are going to tumble amid a lot of volatility.  As of this writing, many of your favorite growth stocks are down 20%, 30%, or more in just a short few months.
importantArticles.title: 2 Growth Stocks That Could Go Parabolic

importantArticles.headline: Wall Street analysts are becoming increasingly bearish on Tesla (NASDAQ: TSLA).  Following the car maker's first-quarter deliveries announcement, Wedbush analyst Daniel Ives called the report a "disaster" and said CEO Elon Musk needs to "get his act together."  Wells Fargo analyst Colin Langan, meanwhile, has been far more critical of the stock, with an "underweight" rating and $130 price target on it.
importantArticles.title: A Wall Street Analyst Says Tesla Stock Could Plunge 50%. Is It Time to Sell the Stock?

importantArticles.title: Former Microsoft CEO Steve Ballmer says companies need to continue to invest despite tariff turmoil
